This concentration prepares students for careers in fields such as data science, actuarial science, and biostatistics, as well as for graduate studies in statistics or related fields.
ScholarshipAmount: Merit awards for first-year students range from $3,000/year to full-ride scholarships.

Description:
The Department of Aerospace Studies provides an opportunity for students to complement their degree with an Aerospace Studies minor. The Aerospace Studies minor is available to any student on campus, including students enrolled in Air Force ROTC. The minor requires a minimum of 15 credit hours of Aerospace Studies courses (AERO prefix courses), 9 of which must be at the 3000-level or above.
The minor is designed for students interested in learning more about the United States Air Force and Space Force and their roles in national defense, leadership, ethics, and communication. It provides a foundation for students interested in military service or careers in defense-related industries.

ProgramName: Minor in African American and Diaspora Studies
Requirements: The Minor in African American and Diaspora Studies requires 18 credit hours of coursework. Students must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.0 to declare the minor.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The minor in African American and Diaspora Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to introduce students to the histories, cultures, and intellectual traditions of people of African descent. Students will engage critical questions related to race, identity, gender, sexuality, class, and nation in the context of the United States and the wider African Diaspora. The minor will offer students analytical and theoretical frameworks for understanding the varied experiences of Black people, while also fostering an appreciation for their diverse contributions to human civilization.

Requirements: To declare a minor in Africana Studies, students should see the Africana Studies undergraduate coordinator. The Africana Studies minor consists of 18 credit hours. Students must complete all coursework for the minor with a grade of C or above.
Description:
The African Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give undergraduate students a broad understanding of the African continent and its diverse peoples, cultures, and institutions. The program helps students develop analytical tools to understand the historical and contemporary challenges facing African societies and their relationships with the global community.
Students who pursue the minor will take courses across disciplines, including Anthropology, Art and Art History, Communication Studies, Dance, English, History, Languages and Culture Studies, Music, Political Science and International Studies, Religious Studies, and Sociology.
The minor requires 18 credit hours, including a 3-credit core course and 15 credit hours of electives from an approved list of courses. At least nine of the 15 elective credits must be at the 3000-level or above. Students must maintain a minimum GPA of 2.0 in courses counted toward the minor. For more information, please contact Dr. Dylan Craig, Director of the African Studies minor.

ProgramName: Minor in American Indian and Indigenous Studies
Requirements: To declare a minor, a student must be in good academic standing (2.0 GPA) and complete a Change of Major/Minor form with their major advisor or in the college that houses their major.
Description: The American Indian and Indigenous Studies (AIIS) Minor at UNC Charlotte is an interdisciplinary minor designed to provide students with a foundational knowledge of the diverse cultures, histories, literatures, social issues, and political sovereignty of Indigenous peoples across the Americas. The minor offers students the opportunity to learn from multiple perspectives (humanities, social sciences, health, education, arts, and languages) and to engage in critical analysis and thoughtful discussions regarding topics such as tribal sovereignty, cultural revitalization, environmental justice, health disparities, and the ongoing impacts of colonialism. The AIIS minor prepares students to engage effectively and ethically with Indigenous communities and to advocate for social justice in diverse professional fields and graduate programs. It complements a wide range of majors including, but not limited to, Anthropology, Communication Studies, Criminal Justice, Education, English, History, International Studies, Political Science, Public Health, Psychology, Social Work, Sociology, and Women’s and Gender Studies.

Requirements: Undergraduate students in good academic standing are eligible to apply.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The American Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a broad understanding of the United States. Through the minor, students learn to critically analyze the many dimensions of American culture, including its history, literature, arts, and social movements. Students learn to use different disciplinary approaches (from fields such as history, English, political science, sociology, religious studies, and art history) to examine American life. The minor encourages students to consider the complexity of American culture, its diversity, and its place in the world. The American Studies minor helps students to develop skills in critical thinking, research, and communication, which are valuable in a wide range of careers.

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Anthropology minor provides students with a broad background in the subfields of cultural anthropology, archaeology, biological anthropology, and linguistic anthropology. An anthropology minor offers students an understanding of human diversity across time and space. The minor consists of 18 credit hours of anthropology courses, including 6 credits of core courses and 12 credits of electives. The minor is appropriate for students in any major, as anthropology courses complement a wide range of academic interests. For example, students interested in international relations, human health, social justice, or cultural heritage could benefit greatly from the coursework in this minor.

ProgramName: Minor in Applied Sciences and Engineering
Department: The William States Lee College of Engineering
Description: The Applied Sciences and Engineering Minor provides an interdisciplinary program of study open to students from all colleges. The Minor provides opportunities for students to learn how to apply the scientific method and engineering principles to solve real-world problems. The coursework and project-based learning experiences are designed to enhance students’ critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, creativity, innovation, and teamwork. Students who complete the Minor will be well-prepared for a variety of careers in industry, government, and academia, as well as for further graduate study in science and engineering.

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Arabic Studies focuses on the language, literature, and culture of the Arab world. The program also provides insights into the religions and societies of Arabic-speaking people and addresses current issues and challenges in the Arab world. Students completing the Minor in Arabic Studies will be able to demonstrate: Proficiency in Arabic language at an intermediate level, Knowledge of the history, societies, and cultures of Arabic-speaking people, Understanding of Arab literature and intellectual traditions.

Requirements: Students can declare the Minor in Archaeology at any time. Students should declare the minor as early as possible in order to receive proper advising. To declare the minor, students should contact the program coordinator.
Description: Archaeology is the study of human societies through material culture, focusing on societies and their interactions across time and space. The interdisciplinary minor in Archaeology introduces students to the principles, methods, and theories of archaeology while providing them with a historical and comparative understanding of the material record of human cultural adaptation. The minor examines major trends in world archaeology, from the beginnings of human culture to the more recent past. A variety of courses are offered, ranging from Old World archaeology (e.g., Egyptian, Near Eastern, Greek and Roman) to New World archaeology (e.g., North, Middle, and South America). The minor also provides courses on the history of archaeology, archaeological methods, and archaeological theory. Students are encouraged to develop their interests through electives and experiential learning in the field or laboratory.

Requirements: Students who wish to declare a Minor in Art History must have a GPA of at least 2.0. The minor is declared online.
Description: The Minor in Art History offers an opportunity for students in any discipline to engage with the study of art, architecture, and visual culture from a global perspective. Courses focus on the analysis of visual objects, the historical contexts in which they were created, and the various ways they have been interpreted throughout history. Minors will learn research methods and theoretical approaches used in the discipline of art history while honing their skills in visual analysis, critical thinking, and written and oral communication. The minor offers flexibility for students to explore a range of art historical periods and geographies while developing a focused area of interest. Students may opt to complete an internship to gain practical experience in the field.

Requirements: Students who wish to declare a minor in Asian Studies must meet with the program director. Students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0.
Description: The minor in Asian Studies is a sixteen (16) credit hour interdisciplinary program in Asian cultures and civilizations. The minor is sponsored by the Department of Global Studies with contributing faculty from Anthropology, Art and Art History, Dance, Geography and Earth Sciences, History, Languages and Culture Studies, and Political Science and International Studies. The minor provides students with a broad and interdisciplinary understanding of Asian cultures, history, and current events. Through its interdisciplinary approach, the minor enables students to appreciate the richness and diversity of Asian cultures from a variety of perspectives. It provides training for employment in federal, state, and local governments, international organizations, and multinational corporations and prepares students for graduate studies in international affairs.

ProgramName: Minor in Baccalaureate Education in Science and Teaching (BEST)
Description: The Baccalaureate Education in Science and Teaching (BEST) Minor is designed to broaden STEM majors’ career opportunities by preparing them to teach high school science, mathematics, or computer science. The minor is offered for STEM majors at UNC Charlotte who desire to add high school licensure to their degree.

Requirements: To declare this minor a student must have a GPA of at least 2.0.
Description: The Minor in Behavioral Science offers a single general concentration. This interdisciplinary minor allows students to apply the tools and concepts of multiple behavioral science disciplines, including psychology, sociology, anthropology, geography, political science, and economics, to analyze real-world problems. The coursework is designed to help students understand the many factors that influence individual, group, and organizational behavior, and develop critical thinking and communication skills through the study of diverse perspectives on human behavior. It complements a wide array of majors, providing students with a valuable credential and enhancing their ability to address complex issues in various professional settings, including health care, education, public policy, and business.

Requirements: Students can declare this minor by using the online program declaration system in Banner Self-Service. A grade of C or above is required in all courses for the minor.
Description: The minor in biology offers a valuable credential for students majoring in other sciences or in fields requiring a fundamental knowledge of biology. The minor is also open to students in other colleges. The minor requires a minimum of 18 semester hours with a minimum GPA of 2.0 in the minor and an overall GPA of 2.0 in courses applicable to the minor. A grade of C or better is required in each course counted toward the minor.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, special talent, or financial need

Department: College of Computing and Informatics and College of Liberal Arts & Sciences
Description: The Undergraduate Minor in Bioinformatics provides students with a foundational understanding of the principles, methodologies, and applications of bioinformatics. It is designed for students interested in the interdisciplinary field that combines biology, computer science, mathematics, and statistics to analyze and interpret biological data. Students pursuing this minor will gain expertise in computational tools and techniques used to manage, analyze, and visualize large biological datasets, such as genomic, proteomic, and transcriptomic data. The curriculum covers key areas including sequence alignment, phylogenetic analysis, gene expression analysis, and structural bioinformatics. This minor prepares students for careers or further studies in bioinformatics, computational biology, biotechnology, and related fields, equipping them with the necessary skills to address complex biological problems using computational approaches.

Requirements:
The Minor in Business Administration is available to students in all colleges at UNC Charlotte except the Belk College of Business. Students must meet all course prerequisites and have a minimum 2.5 overall GPA to be admitted to the minor. A minimum grade of C is required in each course in the minor.

The 18-credit hour minor requires the following courses:
ACCT 2121 Principles of Financial Accounting (3)
ECON 2101 Principles of Economics-Macro (3)
ECON 2102 Principles of Economics-Micro (3)
INFO 2130 Introduction to Business Computing (3)
MGMT 3140 Management and Organizational Behavior (3)
MKTG 3110 Principles of Marketing (3)

Description: A minor in Chemistry is designed for students who want to develop a fundamental understanding of chemistry, but who are not majoring in chemistry. This minor can complement a variety of majors in the College of Liberal Arts & Sciences, the College of Engineering, and the College of Health & Human Services, among others. Students will gain knowledge and skills in general, organic, and analytical chemistry, as well as an introduction to physical and inorganic chemistry concepts. The minor provides a strong foundation for students interested in careers requiring a basic understanding of chemical principles or for those considering graduate studies in interdisciplinary fields.

Requirements: Students who want to declare a minor in Chinese should fill out the online form.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Chinese introduces students to the Chinese language and culture through a series of language, culture, and literature courses. Students must complete at least 18 hours of coursework above the 1201 level, and must earn a grade of C or above in all courses used to satisfy the requirements of the minor.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $369.38, Out-of-State: $1,078.88 (Tuition & Fees per credit hour for 2023-2024)

ProgramName: Minor in Civic Life and Leadership

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: A Minor in Classical Studies complements almost any major and provides a strong foundation for future study in a variety of fields, including archaeology, art history, law, medicine, museum studies, and many others. Our Classical Studies program offers courses in Greek and Latin languages, Classical Literature (in translation), Greek and Roman history, archaeology, mythology, and art. Courses are taught by award-winning faculty with a wide range of expertise. A Classical Studies minor can broaden your knowledge and perspective in a variety of fields. Because Classical Studies focuses on close reading and analysis of texts, ancient authors, and historical contexts, students develop excellent critical thinking, communication, and problem-solving skills which are highly valued by employers. It is a particularly good foundation for further study in areas such as Law, Medicine, and Graduate studies in the Humanities.

Requirements: To declare a minor in Climate Change, students must have a GPA of at least 2.0. A minor in Climate Change requires 18 credit hours. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or better. At least half the credit hours must be taken at UNC Charlotte. Courses taken on a Pass/No Credit basis may not be used toward the minor. Students must take courses from three categories as listed below: Required Core Courses, Climate System, and Human Dimensions.
Fees: In-State: $12,002/year, Out-of-State: $42,442/year (based on 2023-2024 full-time undergraduate tuition and fees)
Description: The Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences offers a minor in Earth and Environmental Sciences for students who wish to supplement their major with knowledge about the Earth System (e.g., geology, meteorology, oceanography) and the environment (e.g., pollution, environmental impacts, and natural resources).

Requirements: The minor in coaching education is an 18-credit hour minor offered by the Department of Kinesiology. The minor requires six (6) credit hours of required coursework, and 12 credit hours of elective coursework from an approved list of courses. A minimum GPA of 2.0 is required in the minor coursework. To declare the minor, students must have a 2.0 GPA, meet with the Minor Advisor, and complete the “Change/Add Major/Minor” form in Banner Self-Service.
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Fees: In-State: $7,490 per year; Out-of-State: $21,136 per year
Description: Students interested in coaching at any level benefit from Lasell's Minor in Coaching. Designed to complement any major, the Minor provides students with fundamental knowledge in sport psychology, injury prevention, strength and conditioning, and sport administration. Graduates are prepared to seek coaching positions in a variety of settings from youth sports to high school and collegiate sports. Students may also obtain national certification from the American Sport Education Program (ASEP).

Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary study of mind, brain, and intelligence. It explores how we perceive, think, remember, learn, make decisions, and use language. The Minor in Cognitive Science is designed to give students exposure to the theories and methodologies used by researchers in psychology, computer science, philosophy, and linguistics to study cognition, and to prepare them for advanced study and research in cognitive science.

The minor draws courses from Psychology, Computer Science, Philosophy, and Languages and Culture Studies. It requires a total of 18 credit hours, including nine hours of core courses and nine hours of elective courses. The elective courses must be selected from at least two different departments. A maximum of six credit hours can be counted toward both the student’s major and the minor. In addition, students must earn a minimum grade of “C” in all courses counted toward the minor.

The minor is suitable for students in a wide variety of majors, including psychology, computer science, philosophy, biology, chemistry, linguistics, mathematics, education, and health sciences.

The Comparative Literature minor offers students an opportunity to explore world literature through a critical approach that cuts across national and linguistic boundaries and relates literary studies to other disciplines. It introduces students to methods of literary and cultural analysis drawn from a variety of intellectual traditions.

ProgramName: Minor in Computational and Applied Mathematics
Requirements:
The minor in Computational and Applied Mathematics consists of 18 credit hours. Students must have a grade of C or above in all courses used for the minor. Students must also satisfy all prerequisites for the courses in the minor.

Note: All of the required and elective courses in this minor require either MATH 2241 or MATH 2242 as a prerequisite.

Required Courses (9 credit hours)
- MATH 2164 - Matrices and Linear Algebra (3)
- MATH 2171 - Differential Equations (3)
- STAT 2122 - Introduction to Probability and Statistics (3) or STAT 3122 - Introduction to Mathematical Statistics (3)

Electives (9 credit hours)
Choose nine hours from:
- MATH 3163 - Introduction to Mathematical Modeling (3)
- MATH 4121 - Introduction to Numerical Analysis (3)
- MATH 4122 - Numerical Solutions of Differential Equations (3)
- MATH 4141 - Introduction to Operations Research (3)
- MATH 4165 - Applied Matrix Theory (3)
- STAT 4123 - Applied Regression Analysis (3)
- STAT 4128 - Applied Time Series Analysis (3)
Description: The minor in Computational and Applied Mathematics is designed for students who desire to learn advanced mathematical, statistical and computing skills for modeling, simulation, and analyzing complex problems in science, engineering, and business. A minor in Computational and Applied Mathematics helps students develop the critical mathematical and computational skills needed to be successful in high-technology industry, government labs, or graduate study.

Requirements: To declare a Minor in Computer Science, students must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.5 and must have completed the prerequisite courses with a grade of C or above: MATH 1120 or MATH 1241 and one of the following: ITCS 1212 and ITCS 1212L, or ITCS 1214 and ITCS 1214L. A grade of C or above must be earned in each course in the minor.
Description: The Computer Science Minor provides students with an introduction to foundational concepts and skills related to computer science, including software design and development, problem-solving, data structures, algorithms, and computer systems. It is designed to complement a student’s primary major by providing a solid understanding of computing principles applicable to various disciplines, preparing them for a technology-driven world and enhancing their career prospects.

Requirements: Students must be in good academic standing with a minimum GPA of 2.0.
Description: The minor in Drama provides students with an opportunity to integrate theatrical studies with other academic and artistic disciplines. The Drama Minor offers courses in acting, directing, design, theatre history and literature. The minor provides a well-rounded foundation in the performing arts and is excellent preparation for continued study in theatre and drama. Additionally, it offers many opportunities for students to participate in productions.

Requirements: To declare a Minor in Economics, a student must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.0. Students must meet with an advisor in the Belk College of Business Niblock Student Center to declare the minor.
Description: A minor in Economics provides students with a general background in economic principles and how they are applied in contemporary society. Students will develop an understanding of macroeconomic issues such as inflation, unemployment, and economic growth; and microeconomic issues such as consumer and firm behavior, market structures, and the impact of government policies. In addition, students will learn to analyze a wide variety of economic issues that affect business and society. Students completing the minor will have a strong foundation for understanding current events and making sound business and personal decisions.

The Minor in Secondary Education at UNC Charlotte is designed for students who are pursuing a bachelor’s degree in a content area, such as English, Math, or Science, and are also interested in careers in teaching at the secondary level (grades 9-12). This minor combines relevant coursework in education with practical field experiences, preparing students to become effective and impactful educators. While this minor does not lead to an initial teaching license, it provides a strong foundation for those interested in teaching, and prepares students for a master’s degree program that can lead to licensure.

Requirements: Students wishing to declare a Minor in English must have a minimum overall GPA of 2.0.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences

Requirements: No special academic requirements above those for the University. Students can declare this minor through Banner Self-Service.
Description: The Minor in Entrepreneurship is designed to complement any major and provides students with skills to create new ventures, lead entrepreneurial initiatives in established organizations, and engage with the broader entrepreneurial ecosystem. The minor emphasizes an experiential learning approach, providing students with hands-on opportunities to develop entrepreneurial skills such.

Requirements: To declare a minor in Environmental Health Science, students must have a 2.0 GPA and should meet with an academic advisor in the Public Health Sciences department.
Description: The Earth and Environmental Sciences Minor provides students with fundamental knowledge in the Earth and Environmental Sciences beyond that provided by general education courses. The minor complements many science and non-science majors, and prepares students for a wider range of career and graduate school options. It is an excellent way for students in other science disciplines to augment their studies, for students in other disciplines to broaden their understanding of Earth and Environmental issues, or to explore areas of interest within the sciences. The minor requires 18 credit hours of courses, including at least 9 credit hours at the 3000 level or above. Students must maintain a minimum GPA of 2.0 in courses counted toward the minor. Specific course options are described in the University Catalog. This minor is open to all students including Earth and Environmental Sciences majors.

Requirements: Students who wish to declare a minor in Environmental Sciences should consult with one of the Program Directors listed below to develop an approved plan of study. To declare a minor, a student must have a GPA of at least 2.0. A grade of C or above is required in all minor courses.
Description: The Minor in Environmental Sciences provides students with interdisciplinary perspectives and knowledge needed to understand, evaluate, and address diverse environmental issues such as climate change, biodiversity loss, deforestation, water and air pollution, and food and water security. The minor covers scientific, social, economic, and policy aspects of environmental problems. It offers students the opportunity to learn about the various dimensions of current environmental challenges and solutions from different disciplinary points of view by taking courses in biology, earth sciences, economics, geography, public health, and other fields. The Minor can easily complement any major and strengthen students' skills and knowledge relevant to careers in environmental conservation, protection, restoration, and management, sustainability, public policy, and environmental education.

ProgramName: Minor in European and Russian Studies
Requirements: The Minor in European and Russian Studies requires 18 credit hours. No more than six credit hours of transfer credit may be applied to the Minor.

Description: The interdisciplinary Minor in Food Studies explores food from a variety of perspectives including its production, distribution, consumption, and waste, as well as its social, cultural, historical, political, and economic impacts. Food Studies takes an expansive view of food, drawing on faculty expertise in fields as diverse as English, Communication Studies, Geography and Earth Sciences, History, Languages and Culture Studies, and Public Health. The Minor allows students to pursue their interest in food in a focused and rigorous way while building valuable analytical and methodological skills for future professional success. Students will learn how to analyze food systems critically and to apply a Food Studies lens to a variety of topics and issues. The minor requires 18 credit hours, consisting of a 3-credit core course (FSST 2100: Introduction to Food Studies), and 15 additional credit hours of approved coursework drawn from the list of approved electives. At least 6 of the 15 additional credit hours must be at the 3000-level or above. No more than 6 credit hours of approved transfer courses may be applied to the minor.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, Financial-need based, College and Departmental, Athletic

Requirements: The Minor in French requires 18 credit hours of French coursework at the 2000-level and above. All coursework must be completed with a grade of C or above. Students must take FREN 3201 and FREN 3202 (or FREN 3203). The remaining 12 credits may be chosen from any FREN courses at the 2000-level or higher. At least nine (9) of the 18 credit hours must be taken at UNC Charlotte. No course taken on a Pass/No Credit basis may be applied to the minor. Students may not major and minor in French.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The minor in French is an excellent way for students to complement any major with additional language, cross-cultural, and international skills. A minor in French allows students to develop advanced linguistic proficiency and cultural competence, both highly valued in today’s globalized world. Learning French opens doors to careers in international business, diplomacy, healthcare, education, social work, global health, and many other fields. The Department of Languages and Culture Studies offers a variety of courses in French language, literature, culture, and civilization, from elementary to advanced levels. Classes are taught by expert faculty in the field, who are dedicated to helping students achieve their academic and professional goals. Students are strongly encouraged to participate in a study abroad program in a French-speaking country, for which numerous options are available.

The Bachelor's Degree in Geographic Information Science (GIScience) is an interdisciplinary program designed to provide students with a strong foundation in GIScience concepts, theories, and applications. The program integrates knowledge from geography, computer science, statistics, and other related fields to equip students with the skills needed to analyze spatial data, develop mapping applications, and solve real-world problems. Graduates of the program are prepared for careers in various sectors, including urban planning, environmental management, public health, business, and government, where spatial data analysis and visualization are critical.

Requirements:
To declare a Minor in Geography, a student must have a GPA of at least 2.0 and have earned a C or above in at least one GEOG course at UNC Charlotte.

The Minor in Geography requires 18 credit hours of coursework in Geography. At least nine of the 18 credit hours must be taken at UNC Charlotte. A grade of C or above must be earned in each course of the minor.
Description: The minor in Geography is administered by the Department of Geography and Earth Sciences. Students who minor in Geography gain insight into the dynamic processes that shape our world, from physical environments to human populations. Geographers study these phenomena and processes at local to global scales. The minor offers students the opportunity to learn foundational concepts in physical geography, human geography, and geographic information science (GIS). This minor is an excellent complement to majors in the social sciences, natural sciences, and other interdisciplinary areas of study. Graduates with a Geography minor are prepared for a variety of careers in both the private and public sectors including environmental management, urban and regional planning, cartography, and many others.

Requirements:
Students must have a GPA of at least 2.0 to declare a minor. A grade of C or above is required in all courses used to fulfill the minor. The minor in Geological Sciences consists of 18 credit hours.

Required Courses (7 hours):
- ESCI 1101 Earth Sciences - Geosphere (3)
- ESCI 1101L Earth Sciences - Geosphere Laboratory (1)
- ESCI 2102 Earth Sciences - Historical Geology (3)

Electives (11 hours):
- Select 11 hours of ESCI or GEOL courses at the 2000 level or higher.
Description: The Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences offers a minor in Geological Sciences. A minor in Geological Sciences consists of 18 semester hours. Six hours must be at the 3000-level or above. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or above. To declare the minor, a student must have a GPA of 2.0 or greater. The minor requires a minimum of 18 semester hours in Geology courses, with at least six hours at the 3000 level or above. No more than six semester hours of transfer credit may be applied to the minor. No more than six semester hours of applied credit can be counted towards the minor. No more than three hours of GEOL 4600 may be applied to the minor.
CostPerCredit: In-State: $445.25 per credit hour; Out-of-State: $1,764.75 per credit hour
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, Need-based, Field Camp Support, Research Support

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: A minor in German provides students with linguistic and cultural skills that prepare them for a wide range of careers in education, communication, business, industry, and government. The German language program aims to develop students’ communicative competence and cultural knowledge through rigorous language training, courses in German literature, linguistics, film, and culture, and study abroad opportunities. Students of German develop critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills applicable to many fields. The minor may be combined with a major in any field. German is an important language in business, international relations, sciences, and the arts.

Requirements: If you are a currently enrolled UNC Charlotte student and would like to declare a minor, you must complete the online form available through Banner Self-Service in my.charlotte.edu. If you are not a currently enrolled UNC Charlotte student, you must first apply for admission to the University. Students minoring in German Studies must complete 18 credit hours beyond the 1202 level. A C or better is required in all courses for the Minor.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in German Studies is designed to equip students with proficiency in the German language and a comprehensive understanding of German-speaking cultures. Through a blend of language courses, literature, and cultural studies, students will develop critical thinking skills and a global perspective. The program aims to foster intercultural communication skills, preparing students for diverse careers or further academic pursuits where knowledge of German is an asset.
CostPerCredit: Undergraduate tuition rates for 2024-2025 are $202.15 per credit hour for NC residents and $777.99 per credit hour for non-residents. Additional fees apply.

Description: The Film Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give undergraduates a coherent understanding of film both as an art form and as a social, political, and economic force. Students are introduced to the formal properties of film; to historical developments in both American and international cinema; and to critical theories concerning various approaches to film study. With courses in departments such as English, Communication Studies, Languages and Culture Studies, and History, the minor draws on a wide range of expertise and perspectives across campus. The minor provides a foundation in film studies for students in any major and prepares them for further study in graduate programs or for careers in the film industry.

ScholarshipAmount: Varies; some scholarships cover the full cost of attendance.

Requirements: Students who wish to declare a minor in Greek should schedule a meeting with a department advisor. A grade of C or above is required in all courses counting toward the minor.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Greek is an excellent complement to degrees in fields such as Classics, History, Philosophy, Religious Studies, English, Political Science, and Art History, as well as many others. Through the study of the Greek language and culture, students will broaden their understanding of Greek civilization and its influence on the modern world. Courses expose students to the origins of Western literature, history, philosophy, drama, and political thought and provide insight into Greek perspectives on human life, society, and the cosmos. Students will gain proficiency in reading and understanding ancient Greek and will learn to analyze primary sources critically. The Minor in Greek supports career paths in education, law, medicine, government, library science, ministry, and journalism, among others.

Requirements: Students must be in good academic standing at the University to declare a minor.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Haitian Creole Minor, offered through the Department of Languages and Culture Studies, provides students with proficiency in Haitian Creole, a language spoken by over 12 million people worldwide. Haitian Creole is an important language in Florida, New York, Boston, Montreal, and other metropolitan areas that have large Haitian diasporas. It is the language of Haiti, an important partner of the U.S. in the Caribbean. A minor in Haitian Creole will give students a competitive advantage for careers related to health, social work, law, education, business, and other service professions, particularly in south Florida and other regions with large Haitian populations. Many of our students have chosen to pair Haitian Creole with a major in Health Systems Management, Political Science, International Studies, Nursing, or Spanish.
ScholarshipType: Merit Scholarships, Need-Based Scholarships, External Scholarships

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences

Requirements: Students can declare the minor in History online using the form found on the Office of the Registrar's website. If you have questions about whether the minor is a good fit for you, please reach out to the History Department’s Director of Undergraduate Studies.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in History is designed for students who desire to supplement a major in another field with a strong grounding in historical studies. Through a combination of coursework covering various periods and regions, students will develop critical thinking, research, and analytical skills. The minor offers flexibility, allowing students to explore their historical interests while complementing their primary academic pursuits.

Requirements: Students must be a degree-seeking undergraduate at UNC Charlotte and in good academic standing. A minimum GPA of 2.0 is required in the minor coursework. At least 9 credit hours must be taken at UNC Charlotte. A maximum of two courses (6 credit hours) may be used to satisfy the requirements for both a major and this minor. No course with a grade of D can be used to fulfill the requirements of the minor.
Description: The Minor in Information Science provides students with the fundamental knowledge and skills of information science including aspects related to people, information, and technology. It focuses on the life cycle of information in organizations, how people interact with information and technology, and how information and computing technologies are used to support organizational processes. The minor is suitable for students in a wide variety of majors, especially those in Business, Communication, Education, Psychology, and Sociology.

Fees: In-state: $7,436/year; Out-of-state: $21,189/year (for 2023-2024, includes tuition and fees)
Description: A minor in Latin American Studies at UNC Charlotte provides students with a multidisciplinary approach to the study of Latin America and the Caribbean, including their diverse peoples, histories, cultures, politics, and socioeconomic issues. Students have the opportunity to develop linguistic proficiency in Spanish or Portuguese, and gain regional expertise, critical thinking, and communication skills applicable to careers in a wide array of fields, including education, government, business, non-profit organizations, international relations, and graduate studies. Students can choose from a range of courses in departments such as Africana Studies, Anthropology, Art History, Communication Studies, Dance, Economics, English, Geography and Earth Sciences, Global Studies, History, Languages and Culture Studies, Music, Political Science and International Relations, Religious Studies, and Sociology. Students are encouraged to pursue an education abroad experience in Latin America or the Caribbean, and internship opportunities are also available locally and abroad.
CostPerCredit: Undergraduate NC Resident (Part-time, 2023-2024): $289.48 per credit hour; Non-Resident: $1,003.48 per credit hour

ProgramName: Minor in Linguistics, Interpretation, and Translation
Requirements: The Minor in Linguistics, Interpretation, and Translation consists of 18 credit hours. A grade of C or above is required in all minor courses. Students must take at least half of the minor coursework at UNC Charlotte. No course taken on the Pass/No Credit basis may be applied toward the minor. Students majoring in a language or language and culture studies may not apply more than two courses (6 credits) from their major to the minor. Students who wish to declare a minor in Linguistics, Interpretation, and Translation must have a minimum overall GPA of 2.0.
Description: The Linguistics, Interpretation, and Translation (LIT) Minor is housed in the Department of Languages and Culture Studies. It is an interdisciplinary minor designed to provide students with a foundational knowledge of linguistics, the academic discipline that studies the structure of language, and its practical application in the fields of interpretation and translation. The minor requires 18 credit hours and is open to all students. The LIT minor provides excellent preparation for careers that involve work with people from diverse linguistic and cultural backgrounds. Potential career paths include interpreters and translators, speech-language pathologists, computational linguists, language teachers, forensic linguists, technical writers, and editors, among others. Students will also be well-prepared for graduate study in related fields, such as linguistics, TESOL, or speech-language pathology.

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Literature and Culture provides students with the opportunity to pursue an interest in literary studies and critical methods outside of the major. It consists of 18 credit hours, including one required course, ENGL 2100: Introduction to Literary Studies, and five elective courses. Students can select courses from across the English Department’s offerings, including courses in American, British, and Anglophone literatures; film studies; women’s and gender studies; and cultural studies.

The minor in mathematics is designed for students who desire a strong mathematical background to enhance their major area of study. The minor is flexible enough to accommodate various interests from application driven students to those with a desire for more theoretical mathematics. The minor also provides a strong foundation for students who might consider graduate study in various quantitative fields. Students will develop an understanding of calculus, differential equations, linear algebra, and discrete mathematics. In addition, students will develop critical thinking skills, problem-solving abilities, and an appreciation for the role of mathematics in various disciplines.

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The minor in Media and Journalism provides students with an overview of media practices and critical analysis skills related to media and journalism. Students will explore the history, ethics, practices, and impact of journalism, public relations, and related media industries. Through a combination of theoretical and practical coursework, students will develop a foundational understanding of media communication, including writing for media, digital content creation, and media literacy.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $1,000 for various departmental scholarships

Description: The Health and Medical Humanities (HMH) minor provides an interdisciplinary approach to healthcare. It complements majors in both the sciences (e.g., Biology, Chemistry, Public Health) and the humanities (e.g., English, History, Philosophy, Religious Studies) and is appropriate for students interested in a broad range of careers in healthcare, including clinical practice, health policy, and public health. Students minoring in HMH will learn to analyze diverse historical, cultural, philosophical, and ethical issues related to health, illness, and medical care. The minor emphasizes the complex interactions of healthcare with society, culture, ethics, and policy and aims to foster critical thinking, communication skills, and an understanding of diverse perspectives. Students complete 18 credit hours, including 6 credits of required courses and 12 credits of elective courses in two clusters. The minor is housed in the Department of Philosophy.

Requirements: Students wishing to pursue a Minor in Music Performance should complete a Minor Declaration form and meet with the Undergraduate Coordinator in the Department of Music. Students pursuing the Minor in Music Performance must successfully audition for applied study.
Description: The Music Performance Minor provides an opportunity for students in any major to continue studying and performing music while pursuing a different academic path. This minor is especially useful for students who enjoy performing, want to improve their performance skills, and wish to perform in large and small ensembles. Participation in ensembles and weekly applied lessons are core to the curriculum.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards vary in amount from a few hundred dollars to several thousand.

ProgramName: Minor in Music History and Literature
Requirements: To declare a minor, a student must complete a Change of Major/Minor form. Students must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.000 to declare a minor. A grade of C or above is required in all courses used to fulfill the requirements of a minor.
Description: The Minor in Music History and Literature provides an in-depth study of the history of Western music. Students completing the Minor will gain knowledge of important figures, styles, and genres in music history, and they will develop skills in critical thinking and research through the study of diverse repertoire and analytical approaches. The Minor will develop students' abilities in written and oral communication, encouraging them to engage with music as an intellectual and cultural phenomenon. The Minor is an excellent complement to majors in the humanities, such as English, History, Philosophy, and Religious Studies, and to majors in other areas within the arts, such as Music, Dance, Theater, or Art History. The Minor in Music History and Literature is not open to students pursuing the B.A. in Music (Music History and Literature concentration).

The minor in Neuroscience and Neurobiology is designed to introduce students to the multidisciplinary study of the nervous system. Students will gain a fundamental understanding of the structure and function of the nervous system, from molecular and cellular levels to systems and behavioral aspects. The curriculum explores topics such as neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, neuropharmacology, developmental neuroscience, cognitive neuroscience, and neurological disorders. This minor is suitable for students pursuing majors in various fields including Biology, Psychology, Health Sciences, Computer Science, and Engineering, providing a strong foundation for those interested in careers in research, healthcare, biotechnology, or further graduate studies in neuroscience. The program emphasizes critical thinking, experimental design, data analysis, and scientific communication.

Requirements: To declare the minor, students should contact the program coordinator.
Description: The North American Studies minor offers students an interdisciplinary approach to understanding the United States, Canada, and Mexico as a continental space. Students explore the region from a variety of perspectives, including history, politics, economics, literature, and culture. The minor requires a minimum of 18 credit hours, including specific courses in History and Political Science, and electives from a range of disciplines. Students will gain a broad understanding of the historical, social, and cultural dynamics that have shaped North America, preparing them for careers in education, public service, international relations, and more.

ProgramName: Minor in Peace, War, and Defense
Description: The Peace, War, and Defense (PWD) Minor provides students an opportunity to learn more about the critical issues surrounding peace and conflict. The interdisciplinary nature of the minor requires students to consider historical, ethical, political, economic, social, and military dimensions of peace and war studies. Through these courses, students will explore topics such as political violence, civil rights, human rights, global affairs, national security, terrorism, international relations, military history, and much more. The minor provides a strong complement for students majoring in areas such as Political Science, History, Criminal Justice, Geography, International Studies, and other disciplines within the College of Liberal Arts & Sciences. Given the interdisciplinary focus, it also pairs well with majors across the university. The PWD minor prepares students to analyze the causes and consequences of conflict and develop skills for conflict resolution. It provides a foundation for careers in government, intelligence, foreign service, law, international organizations, national security, or non-governmental organizations. The minor consists of 18 credit hours; nine (9) hours of required courses and nine (9) hours of electives from an approved list of courses. A grade of C or better is required in all courses counting toward the minor. For more information, please see the Academic Catalog.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, need-based, or a combination of both

Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The minor in Philosophy is designed to introduce students to the main areas of philosophical inquiry and to develop their abilities to analyze complex problems and construct and evaluate arguments. The minor provides a background for students interested in a variety of post-graduate fields, including law, education, business, and theology, and for students pursuing careers in fields that require strong critical thinking, analytical, and communication skills.

ProgramName: Minor in Physical Education Teaching and Coaching
Department: College of Health and Human Services
Description: The Minor in Physical Education Teaching and Coaching requires 18 credit hours and is designed to provide professional preparation for students interested in teaching physical education in public schools and coaching athletics at various levels (e.g., K-12, community). It is intended to complement an undergraduate major (e.g., Exercise Science, Psychology) for students who aspire to careers in fields such as physical education, coaching, athletic administration, and strength and conditioning. The minor includes courses in physical education teaching methods, motor skill development, sport pedagogy, exercise physiology, first aid/CPR, and coaching principles. It does not lead to initial teaching licensure but provides foundational knowledge and skills applicable to various roles in physical activity and sport.

Requirements: Students can declare a minor in Physics by using the online academic plan/minor declaration system. In order to declare a minor in Physics, a student must have completed at least 12 credit hours at UNC Charlotte and have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.0.
Description:
A minor in Physics requires 20 semester hours of Physics courses beyond PHYS 1101 and PHYS 1102. Physics minors are required to take PHYS 2101, PHYS 2102, PHYS 3101, PHYS 3102, and at least one other 3000- or 4000-level Physics course. Any substitution for these courses must be approved by the Department of Physics and Optical Science.

Course List
PHYS 2101 - General Physics I (3)
PHYS 2102 - General Physics II (3)
PHYS 3101 - Modern Physics (3)
PHYS 3102 - Analytical Mechanics (3)

Electives (choose one)
PHYS 3000- or 4000-level (3)

Requirements: To declare a minor in Political Science, a student must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.0. Minors are declared at the department office by completing a 'Declaration of Minor' form. A grade of C or above is required in each course counted toward the minor.
Description: A minor in political science consists of 18 semester hours of course work in political science with a minimum grade of C in each course. The 18 semester hours must include at least 9 semester hours at the 3000-level or above. POLS 1110 Introduction to American Politics and Government or POLS 1120 Introduction to Comparative Politics is required. A maximum of six (6) semester hours from transfer credit may count toward the minor. The specific courses for the minor are to be determined in consultation with the Political Science Department Minor Advisor.

The minor in Public Policy Analysis is designed for students interested in how public policy decisions are made and implemented. The minor focuses on the analytical tools and critical thinking skills necessary for understanding complex policy problems, evaluating policy options, and assessing policy outcomes. Students will develop an understanding of the institutions and processes involved in public policy making, as well as the economic, social, and political factors that influence policy decisions. This minor is suitable for students from a wide range of disciplines who wish to enhance their understanding of public policy and its impact on society. It provides a strong foundation for careers in government, non-profit organizations, advocacy groups, and further graduate study in public policy, public administration, or law.
ScholarshipType: Merit-based, financial need, or a specific area of study

Requirements: To be eligible to declare the Minor in Religious Studies, students must have a cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher. Declaration is done by submitting an online form.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Religious Studies exposes students to the academic study of religion as a human phenomenon. Through a diverse array of courses, students develop a sophisticated understanding of religion, including its history, theories, practices, and impacts on individuals, societies, and cultures across the globe. Students will encounter diverse religious traditions and expressions in various cultural and historical contexts, learn how to analyze and compare them, and critically reflect on the nature of religion as a cultural system. Because the academic study of religion is inherently interdisciplinary, the minor appeals to students across the humanities, social sciences, and professional fields. The minor requires six courses (18 credit hours). For more information, see the Religious Studies program website.

ProgramName: Minor in Social and Economic Justice
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Social and Economic Justice provides students with an interdisciplinary understanding of the causes and consequences of social inequality, poverty, and other forms of oppression. Students will engage with a range of theoretical and methodological approaches to understanding social justice issues, and they will explore strategies for promoting social change. The minor is designed to complement a wide range of majors by providing students with critical analytical skills, ethical reasoning, and a commitment to social justice.
ScholarshipType: merit-based, need-based, or a combination of the two

Requirements: Students wishing to declare a Minor in Sociology should complete the Add/Drop Major/Minor Form. Students must have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.0 to declare the minor. The Minor in Sociology requires 18 credit hours in Sociology. A grade of C or above is required in each course counted toward the Minor. The curriculum is comprised of the following courses: SOCY 1101 - Introduction to Sociology (3), SOCY 3151 - Introduction to Sociological Theory (3), and 12 credit hours of Sociology electives at the 2000 level or above, with at least nine (9) of those credit hours at the 3000 or 4000 level.
Description: Sociology is the scientific study of social life, social change, and the social causes and consequences of human behavior. Sociologists investigate the structure of groups, organizations, and societies, and how people interact within these contexts. Since all human behavior is social, the subject matter of sociology is vast, ranging from the intimate family to the hostile mob; from organized crime to religious cults; from the divisions of race, gender, and social class to the shared beliefs of a common culture; and from the sociology of work to the sociology of sports. The Sociology Minor provides students with an understanding of social life and social forces that shape behavior.

Requirements: To declare a Minor in Spanish, students must have a GPA of 2.0 and should see an advisor in the Department of Languages and Culture Studies.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Spanish offers students the opportunity to develop communicative competence and cultural understanding of the Spanish-speaking world. Students who complete a Minor in Spanish should be able to: 1. Communicate effectively in Spanish at the intermediate-high level as defined by ACTFL guidelines. 2. Understand and analyze a variety of texts and media in Spanish. 3. Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the cultures and societies of the Spanish-speaking world.

Requirements: Students who wish to declare the Minor in Statistics must have a minimum overall GPA of 2.0 and have completed MATH 1241 with a grade of C or above. To declare the minor, students must complete the Declare Minor form via Banner Self-Service.
Description: The Statistics Minor gives students the opportunity to learn statistical analysis skills which are becoming increasingly essential for careers in data science, government, education, and industry. The Minor will provide an understanding of statistical concepts and their application in data analysis and interpretation. Students will learn how to design data collection processes, analyze data using appropriate statistical methods, and effectively communicate the results of their analyses.

The Department of Art & Art History offers a minor in Visual Arts. The minor provides students with the opportunity to gain a broad understanding of the theory, history, and practice of the visual arts. The Visual Arts Minor is an ideal complement to a variety of majors including those in the humanities, social sciences, natural sciences, and business. The minor supports students in developing visual literacy, critical thinking, problem-solving, and creative skills through hands-on engagement with various art forms and theoretical frameworks.

Requirements: Students interested in declaring a minor in Women’s and Gender Studies can do so online using the Add/Drop Minor form available in Banner Self Service. Students must have a 2.0 GPA to declare the minor.
Department: College of Humanities & Earth and Social Sciences
Description: The Minor in Women's and Gender Studies helps students think critically about the roles that gender plays in social, cultural, and political life. Students will gain the skills to analyze how gender intersects with other social categories (such as race, class, sexuality, age, and ability) and how these intersections shape individuals' experiences and opportunities, as well as societal structures and institutions. Through interdisciplinary study, students will learn about feminist and queer theories and methodologies, the history of women's and feminist movements, and contemporary issues related to gender and sexuality. The minor prepares students for a variety of careers in fields such as social justice, advocacy, education, public policy, healthcare, and the arts, and provides an excellent foundation for graduate study in Women's and Gender Studies or related disciplines.
